Building large scenes

The basic idea is to have objects and materials each in their own .blend-file, allowing for several people to work at one big scene at once, as they can edit each file seperatly.

The next image demonstrates the file layout of a big scene.

What are groups?

Groups are a new blender feature (2.42) which allows instancing of a 'group' of objects in another blender scene using an empty to dictate its position, scale and rotation.


Using groups

Say we created a house object with a seperate lantern object with a light in it and a seperate door object. So 4 objects in a file called house.blend. Let's open this file...


Step 1: Creating the group

Select these 4 objects and press CTRL+G this will show a few options:

  • Create a new group
  • Add to existing group (optional: if you already have groups in your blend)

(add menu picture)

Click Create new group the wireframe will now turn green, signalling that the objects now belong to a group. Our group currently has a rather generic name 'Group', let's change that now. Go to Object (F9) and on the Objects and links panel change GR:Group to GR:House01.

(add panel picture)


Step 2: Linking the group

Let's now create a main blend file and call it layout.blend, create a little terrain and paint a road on it.

What's a road without houses along side it?


Press SHIFT+F1

Important: At the bottom make sure Link and Relative Paths are checked!

(add load library picture)

Navigate to our house.blend open it, select Groups and dubbleclick our House01 group.


Step 3: Locating the linked group

Open the outliner change it so it shows the outliner (Not the OOPS schematics) and put the Outliner Display on Groups.

(Add outliner picture)

It should now show the House01 group with Li icon infront of it, telling us it's linked. Rightclick on it, it will show:

  • Unlink
  • Make local

(Add unlink menu picture)

This will unlink the group and remove it from our blend and all instances. (Don't press it unless you want to practise linking :) )


Step 4a: Creating instances the hard way

Put our 3D Cursor somewhere along the road and press SPACE click Add then select Empty. This will create an axis-like representation thing in our world.

(Add Space menu picture)

Select it, now go to Object (F9) and on the Anim settings panel you'll see a button DupliGroup and next to it a editbox with GR: in it.

(Add Anim settings panel picture)

Fill in House01 after the GR: and press the DupliGroup button.

And magic, our house will appear!

SHIFT+D to duplicate the instance a few times and populate the road.


Step 4b: Creating instances the easy way

Put our 3D Cursor somewhere along the road and press SPACE click Add then select Group and press House01.

(Add Space menu picture)

And magic, our house will appear!

SHIFT+D to duplicate the instance a few times and populate the road.


Step 5: Manipulating the instance

You can move/rotate/scale the instance like any other object with G, R and S keys.

Do that now and place your duplicated instances along the road.

These are the only actions you can perform on it!

You can't edit from here out, you'll have to open the house.blend and edit the original objects.

However this means that any changes to the original objects will propagate to all instances.


Notes

The difference with just linking a mesh/object is that a group can contain several objects, so you don't have to merge your objects or link several objects each time.

Even if you're only linking one object it could be wise to still use a group, if you ever plan to add more objects to it later on.


Using groups wisely

Don't use groups for everything!

Example: Take our house.blend, you could have made the door and lantern instances aswell linked in from yet another blendfile and grouped those instances with the house and linked that in turn into the layout.

Although this is perfectly possible, since groups support recursion, it's not wise to use it on such simple objects. (recursion is rather limited, currently only supporting 5 levels) And you're better of just linking those mmeshes.

A better use would be to do something like: 

     door--\
            -- house ==> town(layout) ==> world
  lantern--/

  -- : linked mesh      == : linked group

Have the groups on a higher level, organise your house in a townlayout with sidewalks, barrels and other groups and make all this one group, and eventually link this complete group into your world.


B2CS and groups

Setting Crystal Space specific options, adding materials, setting shader variables and other, all have to be set on the original object.

Instances will be exported with the following name: EmptyName_ObjectName

Since CS doesn't have the notion of groups, the objects are exported as seperate meshes. If you'd like them parented, parent the original objects.
